title-group.article-title: Effects of pressure and temperature on the vibration behavior of sandwich cylindrical shells

abstract.p: In this study, damping characteristics of viscoelastic sandwich cylindrical shell under internal/external pressure and internal temperature are investigated. By implementing finite difference method for irregular grids in the sandwich cylinder, the temperature distribution at each layer is determined. A non-linear model for displacement fields at the viscoelastic core layer is developed to describe the damping characteristics of sandwich cylinder with thin/thick core layer. The effect of dissipation in a pressurized cylinder under harmonic variation of the pressure is also investigated. As shown, deflection increases with time due to the dissipated energy and consequently loss factor is not unique even at a constant frequency.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cylindrical shell structures are widely used for many applications in industries such as boilers, pressurized gas tanks, and aircraft fuselage. Vibration suppression can be achieved in these structures using passive damping treatment. Due to the ability of viscoelastic material to convert strain energy into heat for a wide range of frequencies, it has been used in the damping layer of the sandwich structures. However, this ability is strongly affected by the ambient temperature and the excitation frequency. The analysis of sandwich structures such as beams, plates, and shells using analytical solution, experimental works, and finite element modeling has been reported by many researchers. Loss factor, which is the ratio of the dissipated energy due to the damping and the maximum potential energy, was defined by Ross et al. [1]. Ungar and Kerwin [2] examined this definition and showed that this definition is meaningful for massless structures and it can be applicable for the structure including mass only at the natural frequencies. The sixth-order differential equation for transverse deflection for a three-layered sandwich beam was presented by Mead and Markus [3]. Classical theory has been considerably used to model sandwich structures [4–6]. Rao [7] investigated the effects of shear deformation and rotational inertia for a short sandwich beam. Ramesh and Ganesan [8] developed semi-analytical finite element model based on the first-order shear deformation theory to obtain the damping properties in a cylindrical sandwich shell. Linear distribution for the displacement at the viscoelastic layer was assumed in these studies. A non-linear model for displacement distribution at the core of sandwich beam was proposed by Bai and Sun [9]. Baber et al. [10] examined this non-linear model and proposed an approximate solution using Green function to determine the displacement distribution at the damping layer.

Material properties and damping behavior of viscoelastic materials are strongly frequency/temperature-dependent. Jones [11] used ‘temperature–frequency equivalence’ principle to measure the complex modulus of damping material in terms of temperature and frequency. Lesieutre and Govindswamy [12] implemented an elastic displacement field model with temperature dependence to investigate the heat-dissipating effect on elastomeric specimens by developing a one-dimensional model of simple shear. Teng and Hu [13] investigated the effects of frequency, temperature, and also the dimension of damping material on the vibration characteristics of sandwich beam structures. Hao and Rao [14] presented the analytical formulation to analyze damping in sandwich three-layered beams considering the effect of temperature using shift factor. Moreira et al. [15] developed the viscoelastic modeling based on isothermal model in order to directly contribute to the study of temperature and frequency effects in the model. Gupta and Kumar [16] used the Kelvin model to analyze the vibration of non-homogenous viscoelastic rectangular plates under various values of thermal gradient.

Effects of pre-stress components on the buckling and vibration behavior has been also investigated by many researchers. The vibration analysis of pressurized bare cylindrical shells was studied by Ross et al. [17–19]. Sabri and Lakis [20] used classical finite element method and Sanders shell theory to investigate the dynamic stability of partially fluid-filled cylindrical shells under external and internal pressures. Using semi-analytical finite element method and the concept of geometric stiffness matrix, Ganesan and Pradeep [21] analyzed vibration and buckling behavior of a bare cylindrical cylinder containing hot liquid. The temperature effect on damping behavior of cylindrical sandwich structures was considered by Xia and Lukasiewicz [22]. Ganesan and Kadoli [23], Pradeep et al. [24], and Pradeep and Ganesan [25] presented comprehensive studies on the damping behavior and vibration analysis of piezothermoelastic composite cylindrical shells, composite sandwich beams, and composite sandwich plates under thermal loading. These studies indicate that the damping behavior of sandwich structures is affected by initial stresses and temperature condition. Due to the damping in the sandwich structure, the dissipated energy related to the hysteresis mechanism will be generated in the core layer as a source of heat. This phenomenon has been reported in some applications such as self-heating of elastomeric lead–lag dampers used in articulated rotors of helicopters [26, 27].

In this study, a non-linear model for displacement field at the core layer is developed to achieve better approximation of damping behavior of sandwich structure with thick/thin core layers. Based on the energy balance and using irregular grid, finite difference method is formulated to obtain temperature distribution at each layer due to the temperature inside the sandwich cylindrical shell and heat dissipation caused by cyclic loading. Considering the effects of temperature and frequency on the material properties of damping layer, the vibration behavior of a pressurized sandwich cylindrical shell under the temperature variation has been investigated. The thermal stresses introduced at each layer and also the stress components due to internal/external pressure are obtained to be considered in the vibration analysis using the concept of geometric stiffness matrix in the semi-analytical finite element modeling. Then, parametric studies have been presented to show the effects of all the mentioned parameters on frequency response and damping characteristics of sandwich cylindrical shell. The generated heat raised by dissipated energy not only changes the material properties of the viscoelastic layer, but also can introduce additional thermal stress at each layer. An illustrative example is presented to observe this phenomena for a pressurized cylinder in which the internal pressure periodically varies between certain ranges of amplitudes.

sec.title: Material property of the layers
sec.p:
The material properties of the top and bottom elastic layers (Steel AISI 304) and core viscoelastic layer (Viton_B) are given in Table 1. The material loss factor and shear modulus of the damping core layer highly depend on temperature and frequency, as shown in Figure 3. These data are directly extracted from Nashif et al. [32] in which the temperature–frequency superposition principle was employed to relate viscoelastic properties at different temperatures to the so-called reduced frequency parameter αTω in which αT is the temperature-dependent shift factor and ω the actual frequency. Thus, the material properties can be expressed as (34) where T0 is the reference temperature. Since there is no available explicit formulation to express the properties in terms of temperature and frequencies, all the points in those nomogram are read and digitized with high resolution. According to the data, changing of the material properties with respect to frequencies can be formulated using linear interpolations between each frequency in logarithmic scale. Considering this, an artificial neural network available in MATLAB has been trained to interpolate the shear modulus and loss factor versus temperature and frequency. The effect of temperature rise Tcore(t) within the damping layer due to heat dissipation can be accounted by replacing T in Equation (34) by T + Tcore(t) [33]. It should be noted that the rate of dissipated energy per unit volume in each element is determined using Equation (28) and then substituted in Equation (32) as H to obtain the temperature distribution at each layer in terms of time. sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: In the following paragraphs, first, the developed finite element modeling for a simply supported cylinder under internal/external pressure has been validated by comparing the results with other studies. The temperature distribution using finite difference method for irregular grid is validated by comparing the results to those obtained from finite element method. The natural frequencies and the corresponding loss factors resulting from the linear and non-linear models are also compared. Using the non-linear model, the parametric studies are presented for a clamped–clamped sandwich cylindrical shell.

sec.title: Validations
sec.p:
The natural frequency values under internal and external pressures for a simply supported cylinder are shown in Figure 4. The results are compared to those presented by Sabri and Lakis [20]. The length, radius, and thickness of the cylinder are, respectively, 231, 77.25, and 1.5 mm. The Poisson’s ratio, Young modulus, and density of the material are 0.3, 200 GPa, and 7800 kg/m3, respectively. As it can be seen, excellent agreements between the results are observed. Table 2 provides the comparison between the non-linear and linear models at different natural frequencies and corresponding loss factors for a clamped–clamped sandwich cylinder. The material properties of the elastic and viscoelastic layers are given in Table 1. In this case, the length of the clamped–clamped cylinder is assumed to be L = 2.52 m, the radius a = 0.3 m, and the thickness of bottom, core, and top layers are, respectively, 5, 5, and 1 mm. The comparison shows that non-linear model exhibits more damping characteristics than the linear model. Both models almost result in the same natural frequencies. For these dimensions and the material properties given in Table 1, transient temperatures at the middle point of viscoelastic core and elastic top layers are shown in Figure 5. The results are compared with those obtained by finite element modeling in ANSYS. The ambient temperature is assumed to be 20°C and the heat at the top layer is transferred to the environment where the coefficient of convection is h = 20 W/m2 K. The temperature inside the cylinder relative to the ambient temperature is 40°C and the ends of the cylinder are isolated. As it can be realized, excellent agreement exists between the results. sec.title: Effects of temperature and internal/external pressure on frequency response and loss factor
sec.p:
Increase in external pressure leads to increase in the flexibility. Consequently, as it is also shown in Figure 6, the natural frequencies decrease and the corresponding loss factors increase. Similar results are presented to show the effect of internal pressure on damping and the natural frequencies. As shown in Figure 7, the natural frequencies increase and accordingly the corresponding loss factors decrease because of higher stiffness introduced in the sandwich cylinder under internal pressure. Although external pressure provides more damping, due to decrease in stiffness of the sandwich cylinder, larger deflection is expected, as shown in Figure 8. However, more decrease in relative displacement at the natural frequencies is observed. On the other hand, the static displacement is decreased under internal pressure compared with the unpressurized sandwich cylinder. Due to less damping under internal pressure, more increase in relative displacements at the natural frequencies results. Figure 6.

Effect of internal pressure on loss factor and natural frequency at different circumferential modes. Figure 8.
Frequency response functions at the middle point of pressurized clamped–clamped sandwich cylinder.

The effect of temperature on structural loss factor and frequency response is also investigated. Figure 9 shows frequency response for different ambient temperatures. The results indicate that decrease in loss factor and shear modulus of the damping layer caused by environmental temperature leads to decrease in damping characteristics of the viscoelastic layer. In practice, internal temperature of a cylinder differs from ambient temperature. The effect of internal temperature on the natural frequencies and loss factors at the steady state is shown in Figure 10. This figure also includes the temperature distribution at the mid-section of each layer in the sandwich cylinder. Internal temperature affects the material properties of the core layer and also introduces thermal stresses at each layer. It is interesting to note that increase in temperature has not noticeably affected the natural frequencies except a slight reduction of natural frequencies at higher modes. Referring to Figure 3, it can be seen that the loss factor and real part of the viscoelastic layer decrease in the given temperature range, which should lead to decrease in damping behavior and natural frequencies. However, the resulted pre-stresses due to the thermal loads increase the stiffness of the structure, which somehow counterbalances the reduction of natural frequency by increasing the temperature. Consequently, as observed in Figure 10, the natural frequencies almost remain unchanged except at higher frequencies. However, decline in damping performance of the viscoelastic material and the developed thermal stresses considerably decrease the loss factor. These can also be observed from the frequency response shown in Figure 11. Figure 9.

sec.title: Heat dissipation effect of viscoelastic layer
sec.p:
For a pressurized sandwich cylinder in which the pressure is periodically oscillating during time, according to Equation (32), the mechanical strain energy will be dissipated after each cycle. The internal pressure is assumed to be Pint = 3 MPa and the amplitude of oscillation 1 MPa. The rate of dissipated energy for unit volume should be substituted into Equation (31) as H. This energy will be accumulated inside the viscoelastic layer. Since the conductivity of the viscoelastic material is low, the generated heat will be transferred to constraining layer after long time. The heat then is transformed to the environment through convection. Therefore, the temperature keeps on increasing at the viscoelastic layer, which leads to decrease in loss factor and shear modulus, and consequently larger amplitude of displacement results. This behavior is shown in Figure 12 at f = 100 Hz. For low frequencies, small amount of heat is generated with time compared to the high frequencies. Figure 13 shows the temperature distribution along the axial coordinate of the cylinder at the center axis of core layer for high frequency (f = 400 Hz) after 20 s. Figure 14 also shows the variation of amplitude at the midpoint of core layer for different convection coefficients. As it can be realized, the amplitude reaches its steady state faster under forced convection. From the results, one can conclude that the definition of loss factor is not unique even at natural frequencies. The heat dissipation changes the material properties and also introduces thermal loads in the structure and consequently the structural loss factor changes. Figure 15 shows the hysteresis loops after every 10 s under cyclic loading for free convection. According to the shapes and slopes of the trajectories, the area of the ellipse that represents dissipated energy (and consequently loss factor) is changing during time. Thus, in the definition of loss factor, the number of cycles should also be considered. Figure 12.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The frequency response function and vibration characteristics of a pressurized sandwich cylindrical shell under thermal loading were investigated. Not only pre-stress components (resulted from pressure and temperature) affect the damping properties, but also the change in the material properties of the damping layer due to temperature variation can change the frequency response and vibration characteristics. The internal temperature introduces different temperature distributions and consequently different stress distributions at each layer. The heat dissipation from damping layer releases energy, which can be considered as a heat source in the heat transfer equation. It was shown that the thermal load and change in material properties due to the heat generated change the frequency response. Therefore, not only the temperature and frequency affect the damping behavior, but also a number of cycles of the harmonic loading can affect the damping characteristics of a sandwich structure.
